line.en: 'How are we going to do the flight training?'
Once all of us second-years had gathered, I asked\nAmane that.
Amane has been playing around with a bundle of\ntangled PC cables, so we can only see her from\nthe other side of the desk.
'By flying.'
'Flying??'
I imagined it would be something like... doing\nweight training to build physical strength.
'But I still can't fly, can I?'
There's no way we can fly using those broken\nwings...
'Could you move those boxes that are over there\nby the wall?'
As requested, I tidy away the boxes piled up\nagainst the wall of the garage.
'Whoa, there are piles of things. But, I don't\neven know what they are.'
Since before Amane and the others started coming\nhere, this garage has had many mysterious boxes\nand antique parts left inside.
'What's this? Why are a sword and spear in a\nplace like this?'
'There are some nunchucks over here.'
'There's a broken toy gun too...'
Of course, the sword and the spear are well made\nreplicas.
As for the other things, if I had bought them, I\nwould think
'Why the hell did I buy this...?'
and would definitely regret buying them. There\nare also many things that look like souvenirs,\nthat were bought on school-leaving trips.
I could easily tell that the members of long ago\nmade this garage their own.
'Finished.'
'OK, turn off the lights.'
As the lights were turned off, the inside of the\ngarage became pitch-black.
Amane was operating some kind of machine.
Then, on the wall where all the boxes were\nbefore, a PC screen appears.
'It's a projector.'
'Like in a movie theater...'
Are we going to watch an instructional video?
'Aoi, could you come over here?'
Sitting down in the chair that Amane had\nprepared, I was handed a computer game\ncontroller.
'What are we doing?'
'Like I said, you're going to fly. This is a\nflight simulator.'
'Flight simulator?'
I've heard of them. But, I'm not exactly sure\nwhat they are.
'It's like a computer game. It simulates the\nexperience of flying.'
'Even if you don't actually fly, you can, to some\nextent, learn the controls and the feeling of\nflying a glider.'
'I don't really understand, but it sounds pretty\nuseful.'
'Is this commercially available?'
'No, I made it myself.'
'This is the topography of Kazegaura, and is a\nsimulator specifically for our glider.'
At Amane's command, the screen changes.
Kazegaura, the town that we were all familiar\nwith, was shown as a landscape. It was projected\nonto the wall.
This is shown in pretty CG, which is at least on\nthe level of the cut scenes from RPGs on the\nlatest consoles.
'She really is amazing...'
Ageha mumbles, while looking at the screen being\nprojected.
'This was updated with the latest data yesterday.\nYou should be able to get a very realistic sense\nof flying.'
'OK.'
I show that I am impressed with Amane's amazing\nwork, and get myself fired up.
'Well then, let's begin.'
A glider, modeled in CG appears on the screen.
'Before you learn the controls, I will explain\nthe movements of the glider.'
'The glider movements can be explained as\nrotation on three axes: longitudinal, lateral and\nvertical.'
'First, is rolling.'
On the screen, the 'longitudinal axis' that runs\nalong the length of the fuselage and the movement\nbased on rotation on that axis were displayed.
This movement is called rolling.
'Next is pitching.'
This time, the 'lateral axis', coming out\nsideways from the fuselage, and the movement\nbased on rotation on this axis were shown.
This movement raises, and lowers the nose and is\nknown as pitching.
'Then, finally, is yawing.'
Going through the fuselage vertically was the\n'vertical axis', and the movement based on\nrotation along this axis was displayed.
This movement, yawing, moves the nose left and\nright.
'These are the three basic movements of the\nglider. Do you understand?'
'Yes, I think so.'
'No matter how complex the maneuvers made by the\nglider are, the truth is, they are all\ncombinations of these three movements.'
'That's why the pilot only needs to know how to\noperate these three movements.'
'I see... So the basics are quite simple, then?'
Kotori and Ageha are listening to the\nconversation and nodding along.
'OK, with that in mind, let's try actually\noperating it.'
Amane selects the mode on the PC and the screen\nchanges again.
The sky and the horizon are projected across the\nwall.
'Is this the view from the cockpit?'
'Yes, that's right.'
'Wow, so this is what it looks like?'
The glider is already flying through the air, but\nbecause I'm used to video games, this feels\nincredibly slow.
It doesn't really feel like it's moving forward\nat all.
'Except for take off and landing, and some other\nspecial cases, there are two things you need to\ncontrol.'
'The yoke and the rudder pedal.'
I've seen the cockpit many times, so I know about\nthat.
The yoke is the stick that comes out from between\nthe pilot's legs.
I've seen some scenes in movies where pilots are\nflying fighter planes, and the yoke is the thing\nthat they are holding onto.
It has a button on it, and if you push it, it\nlaunches missiles. Of course, this glider doesn't\nhave anything like that.
It's like the steering wheel of a car.
Then, there are the left and right rudder pedals,\none of each. They are are operated by pushing\nthem with your feet.
'The controller corresponds to each one. The left\nanalog stick is the yoke. The L and R buttons are\nthe rudder pedals.'
I try the analog stick, and the L and R buttons\non the game pad.
It's a little slow but the field of vision in the\ncenter of the screen swings round.
'Whoa!!'
'If you get careless, it will stall and fall to\nthe ground, so watch out.'
'First is the yoke. This controls two of the\nthree movements that I explained just now:\nrolling and pitching.'
'If you move it left and right, the fuselage will\nroll in that direction.'
I move the analog stick, in other words, the\nyoke, slowly to the left.
It's a little slow but the aircraft responds.
The horizon in the middle of the screen leans to\nthe right.
'What makes the aircraft lean when you move the\nyoke?'
'Good question. That is because the yoke controls\nthe ailerons.'
'Ailerons??'
It's like Kotori has a big question mark on her\nface as she hears that unfamiliar word.
'They are wings fitted to the main wings.'

'They are attached to the outside rear of the
main wings. If you move the yoke left, then the
left wing's aileron is raised, and the right
wing's aileron is lowered.'

'When that happens, the lift on the left wing is
reduced, while the lift on the right wing is
increased: the aircraft banks. In other words, it
leans by rotating to the left.'
'Leaning and turning, huh? It's the same as a\nbicycle.'
A bicycle has a handlebar, but you don't turn by\nmoving it left and right. You turn by leaning\nagainst the bike.
'There is one more movement that can be made with\nthe yoke, and that is pitching.'
'Pitching is, in short, moving the nose up and\ndown.'
'If you pull the yoke back, the nose goes up, and\npushing it forward makes it go down.'
I tried pushing the yoke forward.
'Whoa!'
The screen moves, and the percentage of the\nscreen filled with the ground increases.
The aircraft points downwards, and I feel a much\ngreater sense of speed.
'By pointing the nose down, the aircraft drops\nbut the speed also increases.'
'I see...'
I imagine it sliding down on the air.
This time, I tried pulling the yoke back.
I was no longer able to see the horizon.
It felt like it was floating and I realized the\nspeed was dropping.
'How is this controlled? With the ailerons you\ntold us about just now?'

'No, it isn't. Before, we did experiments with
paper airplanes, didn't we? The thing that
controls the up and down movements of the
aircraft is...'
When Kotori was playing around with the tails on\nthe paper airplanes, she made one do a beautiful\nloop-the-loop.
'Oh, the horizontal tail plane!'
Amane nods her head as if to say 'Well done'.
'Pitching. In other words, the up-and-down\nmovements are controlled with a rudder called an\nelevator attached to the horizontal tailplane.'
Of course, we've heard of an elevator before.\nBut, this was different to the type that goes up\nand down in buildings.
'Usually, raising the nose increases lift.'
In other words, the aircraft will rise.
'However, if it is raised too much, it will lose\nlift instead.'
'The airflow will no longer be able to move along\nthe wings, and it will break away.'
'This phenomenon is known as a stall. I don't\nneed to explain what happens if you lose lift.'
You can't fly if there's no lift, and it will\ninevitably fall.
'If that happens, is there nothing to do but\nfall?'
'No, it's possible to straighten it out.'
'A stall can occur at any time, so it's necessary\nto undergo stall recovery training.'
'OK.'
When it is suggested that falling is a\npossibility, I find it hard to breathe.
When you're flying through the air, even a tiny\nmistake can cost you your life.
'Shall we try dropping?'
'Huh?'
Amane pulls back hard on the analog stick.
The nose points further and further upwards, and\nthen...
'It has exceeded the critical angle. It's\nstalled.'
The aircraft stopped moving as if it was\nfloating. Then, the screen started spinning like\ncrazy as it began hurtling towards the ground.
GAME OVER
'It said game over...'
'Well, that's what it's like. In training, stalls\nand spins are caused on purpose, then recoveries\nare practiced.'
'Actually doing that in the air is really scary.\nYou'll think that you are going to die.'
If you're scared of heights, maybe that really is\ntrue...
Because of how well the simulation is made, I got\na powerful enough impression just from the\ngraphics.
Amane selects the mode, and once again, we start\nflying.
'OK, next is the rudder pedal.'
In the simulator, this is controlled with the L\nand R buttons.
'These operate the rudder, which is also known as\nthe directional rudder. It is attached to the\nvertical tailplane.'
'If you press the right pedal, it moves right. If\nyou push the left pedal, it moves left. This\ncontrols yawing.'
'This turns it sideways? But when you turn, you\nuse the ailerons on the wings, right?'
'If you just use the ailerons, the aircraft still\nfaces forwards, and moves like it's slipping\nalong the side it banks on.'
'What does that mean?'
'If it's still facing forward, it would move\ndiagonally, wouldn't it?'
Amane nods.
'By operating the rudder at the same time, you\ncan turn the nose in the direction you want to\nface.'
'Like the handlebars on a bicycle?'
While leaning the bike, you turn the handlebars\nin that direction. If you don't, you won't be to\nturn well.
Using bicycles as an example, leaning the bike\nleft or right is like the ailerons, and the\nhandlebars are like the rudder.
'I see... When you want to turn, you must use the\nailerons and the rudder.'
'That's right. However, that alone is not\nenough.'
'When turning, leaning the aircraft causes a drop\nin lift, and the aircraft will drop down quite a\nlot.'
'To keep as much speed as possible when turning,\nyou need to move the yoke sideways, and also back\na little.'
'When you turn, you must use all of the axes at\nthe same time.'
Using what and when looks like it's quite\nintuitive.
'That's all. Those are the only controls you need\nwhen flying.'
After ending her explanation, Amane turned on the\nlights.
'It's pretty simple, isn't it?'
'Yeah, it is.'
When I heard unfamiliar words like 'aileron' and\n'rudder', it sounded complicated, but once I\ntried it, it was quite easy.
Moving the yoke backwards, forwards, left and\nright, and pressing the left and right pedals.\nThat's all there is to it.
'As long as you don't try any aerial acrobatics,\nthere are almost no difficult controls.'
'The thing you need to ride the glider, is the\npower to find the wind.'
'Find the wind...?'
'Where and what kind of wind is blowing. Where\nthe vertical drafts are.'
'Finding the the wind like that, determines\nwhether you can fly it well or not.'
'So you mean you need, knowledge, experience and\nintuition.'
'Yes, that's correct.'
'For you to learn how to read the instruments,\nfirst, you have to get used to them.'
'Next, you can practice by looking at the\ncomputer screen.'
'Ok, got it.'
I sat down in front of the PC and started\npracticing immediately.
Club activities have finished, and we're on the\nway home.
'It's so hot...'
Ageha is fanning the chest of her sweat-drenched\nuniform.
She sees me looking.
'Huh? What are you looking at?'
She senses me looking at her chest, and asks\ncheerfully.
'You know, you should try to be a little more\nladylike.'
'I can't help it. My chest is the sweatiest\nplace.'
'That's ladylike, isn't it?'
she asks as she carries on fanning herself.
I get a slight feeling that she's trying to show\nme.
'The air conditioning in the garage is pretty\nweak, isn't it? My butt gets really hot.'
says Kotori as she wriggles her backside around.
When it comes to these two...
'It's spacious, and there's no effect of heat\ninsulation from the ceiling.'
It's like a prefabricated building. There's no\nattic, and the heat from the sun transfers\ndirectly to the inside.
Even if we turn on the air conditioning, it only\nhas half the effect.
'It's better than at the Robotics Club though.\nThere are a lot of people, so it gets really\nhumid... from the sweat.'
Listening to Ageha's story, Kotori makes a face\nthat says 'Ewww!
'Alright, I'm going this way.'
We get to the usual fork in the road, where Ageha\nleaves us to go in the other direction.
'See ya.'
'Hey, Ageha.'
'Do you wanna get some ice cream from the\nconvenience store?'
'Yeah sure... but why all of a sudden?'
'You two were saying how hot it is, and I\nsuddenly felt like eating one.'
'You wanna eat one too, Kotori?'
'Huh? Y-...Yeah OK.'
Kotori seems to be thinking about Ageha being\nthere when she answers.
'OK, let's go.'
I start walking ahead.
In the convenience store parking lot, I bite into\nthe ice cream that I had bought.
Hanging out in front of the convenience store is\none of the privileges of being a high school\nstudent.
Ageha got watermelon flavor, Kotori got chocolate\nchip, and I chose Vanilla Monaka.
'So, you prefer the ones sold in cups, Kotori?'
'...Ice cream on a stick melts halfway through,\nand it makes your hands sticky. So, I don't\nreally like it.'
Seems like everyone has their own preferences\nwhen it comes to ice cream.
'Hey, Aoi. How was the simulator?'
'Hmm... I still don't really understand it. It\nwas pretty tricky.'
'Which part was difficult?'
'It just feels kind of inconvenient, you know?\nWhen I think about doing something, I'm not able\nto do it quickly...'
'The feeling I get when I move it, and the speed.\nIt's quite easy to steer though.'
'If there's no wind, the ailerons, rudder, and\nelevator have no effect though.'
'That's right.'
Using the power of the wind to control the\nposition of the aircraft.
Of course, if the wind is strong, small movements\nof the controls have a big effect, and vice\nversa.
However, the glider doesn't have an engine.
You can't easily speed up or slow down.
'If you do one thing, it affects everything else,\nand that's what makes it difficult.'
You can't just think about the current situation,\nyou have to act according to what will happen\nnext.
It means that experience is needed to ride this\nthing.
'Hmmm... Did it feel good to fly it?'
'Well, to be honest, the simulator didn't feel\nthat good at all... You were watching the screen,\nright?'
'Yeah. How should I say... It looked really\nfrustrating.'
'Compared to 3D simulator games, it was nowhere\nnear as exhilarating.'
'Yeah, that's true.'
'It must be a lot different to actually fly\nthough...'
'I think so. I can imagine that somehow.'
How would it feel to fly through the sky in that\nthing, I wonder?
It still feels a bit unclear.
'...It's nice isn't it? I wanna fly too.'
'Why don't you give the simulator a try?'
You can control everything with your hands.
'No, I'm OK. Now is the time for you to do it,\nAoi.'
I'll be patient for now... that's what it seemed\nshe was saying.
Without thinking, Ageha and I look at each other.
'OK, let's hurry up and make the wings, so that\nwe can actually fly it.'
'Yeah.'
If I can quickly become able to fly by myself, I\ncan take Kotori with me.
I might be getting ahead of myself, but it's good\nto have a target.
'Tsk. I didn't win a prize. Pity.'
Ageha finished eating her ice cream, and threw\nthe stick into the trash can.
I've finished eating too, so I throw my Monaka\nwrapper into the trash can.
'Munch, munch...!'
Kotori was still eating, and hurriedly ate the\nlast of her chocolate chip ice cream.
It wasn't as bad as Amane, but, the way she ate\nkind of ruined her 'pretty girl' image.
Then, she rushed over in her wheelchair and came\nto throw the cup into the trash can.
Does she think that if she doesn't do it quickly,\nwe'll leave her behind?
While we were away from Kotori, Ageha had come up\nbeside me.
'Thank you for being so considerate.'
'Whadya mean?'
'For playing dumb. You invited Kotori and I here\nfor our sakes didn't you?'
'...I dunno, did I?'
Looking at me as I quietly play dumb, Ageha\nsmiled cheerfully.
'Oh, sorry to keep you waiting.'
'...You didn't need to rush like that.'
'OK, I'm off now. See you tomorrow!'
'Yeah, see ya.'
'B-Bye.'
We see Ageha off as she waves goodbye. Then, I\npush Kotori's wheelchair along the road back to\nthe dormitory.
